reviewText: *Note: This was written before the Rebirth" update to the game that makes changes to the main story dialogue. I have not played it since this update
recommended: I will revise my review. For now
hoursPlayed: it will remain the same. This is a review of the game I paid for
voteText: played and that the devs were content with for almost six months.\n\nTL
helpfulPercent: DR: Chronicles of a Dark Lord is an ineptly written game with somewhat tolerable combat. The story is cliche
votesHelpful: the characters have no personality or diversity and the game's flow is extremely repetitive. The description promises a game that's dark
votesFunny: but what you get is juvenile
commentsCount: shallow and as dark as something like Naruto. Furthermore
column16:
even though the description promises that you'll get to make decisions that effect the game later that is not the case (aside from choosing whether or not to kill random NPCs).

-------------------------------------

First
column17: I want to point out that one positive review on this page was written by someone affiliated with the developers. Looking at some comments on their Desura page
column18: it seems like this is not uncommon for them. Even if I liked this game this would leave a bad taste in my mouth.\n\nFair warning
column19: there are SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEW.\n\nChronicles of a Dark Lord: Episode 1 Tides of Fate is the kind of game that gives RPG Maker games a bad reputation. It is one of the worst written games I've ever played. If an RPG is poorly written
column20: it fails. This goes double for RPG Maker games
column21: because the graphics are pretty standard across the board (some will have nice character portraits
column22: the portraits in this seem to be generated in RPG Maker) and the gameplay is very rote JRPG fare.\n\nBefore I get into why Chronicles of a Dark Lord is so bad
column23: I will talk about the few things I did like. The random battle system is very nice. It's not really random. There's a meter that fills up as you walk and decreases if you stand still. If it fills up
column24: you enter a battle. There's lots of object hidden around in the environment. My love of RPGs has trained me to check literally everything. In this game it pays off and I like that. Finally
column25: about halfway-ish through the game I found a hidden sword and piece of armor that was so over-powered I breezed through a lot of the game. That definitely helped me keep going. Also
column26: the song during the end credits is pretty good. Marielle Thomas did a great job with it.\n\nSo
column29: the characters have no personality. Well
column31: but everyone is either quiet and serious or kind of goofy. There is hardly any distinction between your party members. Half of them even look the same. If I was forced to describe any of them it would be extremely difficult. That's not good. The characters should be diverse and interesting.\n\nThe main character
column33: is the worst of all. No personality. Towards the end of the game
column34: some characters have a conversation about how he doesn't show emotion. Guess what? That's not interesting. He's just kind of there. Everything interesting about him happened in the prologue and the text crawl between that and the main game. There's supposedly a conflict between the evil path he started down and his decision to not be totally evil. . .WE NEVER SEE THAT.\n\nMagus is supposed to be so dark. The only way the game really shows us that in the main game is that we are given the option to randomly kill some NPCs. That's the problem with the game in general: where's the darkness? This is supposed to be dark and mature
column35: but it's not. The game tries too hard to also be funny and light for it to be dark. For instance
column36: there's one part where you're in a cave and there's a rumble. Magus' wife says something like
column37: "Either Magus is hungry or we better get moving!" The game doesn't have any of the edge it claims to have
column38: but when you throw in lines like that
column40: the conversation with a female NPC where the Dark Lord Magus says he'll come back later to pick her up so she can come visit his kingdom.\n\nHere's a line that just blew my mind: "She is going to cut my breasts off or something if we do not get out of her garden." That's in the game. Or
column41: how about this line which someone says before fighting one of the final bosses: "I am Sapphire Darkwell. . .and I hate cats. It's because of YOU I have to institute a law against cats in Senefarria!" That is some dramatic and dark writing.\n\nThe storyline is really cliche. First
column42: you're traveling around trying to rally people to fight an invading evil. Then
column43: it turns out that (spoiler alert) the bad guys have a hidden agenda. They're trying to summon something to destroy the world. The dumbest trope in the world. Why do they want to destroy the world? What do they gain?\n\nThe script is super repetitive. I'm willing to bet 10% of the game is characters introducing themselves or being introduced. Magus seems to know every character he meets
column44: but I don't. We usually don't really learn who they are
column45: but we're supposed to care about them or be invested in what's going on. One character is recruited
column46: then a side quest immediately becomes available where someone is trying to lure them into a confrontation. I don't know who that enemy was and I didn't care about what was going on. The whole game in general is repetitive. The bulk of it is: go to castle
column48: get permission to go to next world map screen
column50: go to castle. World map screens come in two varieties: Castle and town and bridge/cave/docks or castle and bridge/cave/docks.\n\nThen
column51: there's just weird stuff that makes me think the game was written by a 13-year-old boy. All your party members are female
column52: except for Magus and someone you get at the end of the game. Why? There's no good reason. Also
column53: three of your party members are women who Magus has had sex with. His ex-wife
column54: his current wife and their lover. That's right
column55: Magus has a wife and together they have a lover. Why? How did this happen? What is the attraction? What is the purpose from a writing perspective? It doesn't add anything. None of the three seem to actually be in love
column56: they just call each other "my love." I guess for them to seem like they actually loved each other they would need personalities. Is it so we know how not gay Magus is? Is it so he seems cooler or more awesome? I'm not a prude. If the characters were more developed
column57: if any of it served any purpose
column58: it would be fine. It doesn't
column59: though. There's also a city entirely populated by lesbians.\n\nThere's also just mind-blowingly crazy things. There's a character named Crysta Aier. Later
column63: we recruit Krysta Aier and I thought
column65: I just remembered it wrong." Then
column66: you re-recruit Crysta Aier and have both Aiers. Then
column67: I didn't know what was going on. Finally
column70: I found out that one of them is FROM ANOTHER DIMENSION. That's right. People's dopplegangers just pop in from other dimensions. Then
column71: Magus remembers about the time that happened to him!\n\nOn top of the insanely inept writing
column72: there are other issues. There's no mouse control and muting sounds doesn't completely work. Also
column73: even though the description seems to promise that you'll get to make decisions that effect the game that is not true. The only decisions you get to make are whether or not to kill some random
column74: nameless NPCs.\n\nI know that this review is extremely long
column75: but the game is so flawed in so many ways I had to get it out (if only for my own sanity)."

reviewText: I am only 6 hours in, but definitely worth the 5 bucks I paid for it if not more. Not too far in but there are a few things that jumped out at me right away:\n\n1. It's very much like Dragon Warrior 4, and it borrows concepts from Final Fantasy. They don't try to reinvent the wheel, which is a good thing, eg the thing that revives a dead ally is called a phoenix feather
date: that which cures poison is an antidote. Simple and good.\n\n2. tl;dr - You can avoid battles when you want to /tl;dr. The battle system is turned based, and each character's time bar fills up at a rate based on the character's agility. Time stops when a bar is full. Encounters are not random on the world map or in encounter zones. Instead, a battle bar" fills up with each step you take. When the bar is full
recommended: there's a battle. If you stand still for a second or two
hoursPlayed: the bar will begin to empty until it is.\n\n3. The characters and their abilities are good and balanced
voteText: and they don't contain fluff or spam.\n\n4. They did a good job of taking the elements of classic rpgs that drive you nuts / are overdone / are unrealistic out
helpfulPercent: and instead put in refreshing updates to an older genre. I don't want to give out spoilers but the protagonist is a bad ♥♥♥
votesHelpful: not some wet behind the ears kid who just had his mind blown learning that he's the savior of the world or some whiney teenager with "teen angst." Npcs for the most part don't have duplicate dialog
votesTotal: meaning every npc you talk to has something different to say. They've completely removed unnecessary hyper-morality that is common in old school rpgs. The story and dialogue are interesting but not overbearing. There are many
votesFunny:
many more examples of times you will find yourself smiling just because they did something better than it's been done in the past.

5. Lesbians


I have only a few criticisms of the game at this point
commentsCount: and none of them are "bad."\n\n1. Character sprites in battle are the same as they are on the map
column16: while enemies' sprites in battle are elaborate. I would have made artfully elaborate battle sprites for each of the characters to give them more depth
column18: and make them more likeable over all.\n\n2. There are two areas in the game so far where it seemed to be "laggy
column19: which doesn't make sense because it's basically a super nintendo game. One area had fog" which seems like it could almost make sense
column20: but the other was in a castle i beleive.\n\n3. If you turn off all three sound options (listening to music
column23:
there are two sounds during battle that are still heard. Issuing battle commands and critical strikes.



As you can tell from these "criticisms
column24: there's nothing not to like about this game. Buy it.\n\nI don't often write reviews, but this game only had two at the time of this writing, so i wanted to endorse a good game. I will update this review once I have more time in.

reviewText: Now that the Rebirth update is released, I have no major compaints about this game! Some might be turned off by the broody, almost gothy mood of the characters and story, or by the perhaps inconsistent graphics and fonts, but really, the gameplay is tight, and the writing (with said update) is delightful. It's fairly linear besides the occasional little sidequest, which is fine. For five dollars (or a buck and a quarter during the Summer sale), it's a great deal for those who love oldschool JRPGs!
voteText: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Having played through and beaten this game (non-Steam version) before the Rebirth update, I wanted to see what the changes were. What I found were more detailed in battle character sprites, new music tracks, smoother gameplay, better dialogue, and now I get to have achievements and trading cards with the Steam version. It's a solid RPG. With a great story, challenging bosses, good combat, really good music, and memorable characters (especially Xiria) you can't go wrong.

reviewText:
Where to begin? Chronicles of a Dark Lord is a retro style RPG game, poorly finished. Sometimes the character is confused with the floor through the use of generic textures and excessive dark colors (as if the person playing this game is not realized by the actions of the character and the story about the dark nature of the main character).

Music is terrible. Ok, it's a retro game, but music can be better, the graphics can be improved by using own textures, and not abuse the generic textures.

In the section of the gameplay, does not offer support for the mouse, and does not support all game controllers; so the only option is to play with the keyboard, with all the discomfort that means. Failure to skip all the endless and annoying text scenes makes the game experience even worse.

I have nothing against the games made with RPG Maker. In fact, I enjoyed games like Victim of Xen and Memories of a Vagabond, but this game is far from offering the same game experience.

For the price it costs the game is not worth buying, it's a waste of money.

My score: 3/10

Not recommended.

reviewText:
The very moment I started the game I was pretty impressed. I was squeeling like a silly woman over the characters despite not being that far into the game. I can, without a doubt, say I enjoy the game thus far. I adore what this game has to offer story wise, and the character personalities keep me interested.
The game play is easy to master. One thing I like in particular is the Battle Bar featured at the top. You can avoid battles if you'd wish. The feature actually keeps me playing longer, as I've more time to explore and less time focusing on random battles all the time.

Tldr; I enjoy playing this game. If you're all about the story and character personalities, you'll fall in love. That's all I really focus on in a game. There's nothing mechanical wise that sticks out as faulty. It runs pretty smoothly, especially so with the new patch.

reviewText:
I think this is honestly an above average RPG maker style game, and I can't quite understand what all the whining is about from certain other reviewers and honestly wonder if they played the same game I did.  Maybe they just want more cookie-cutter RPGs.  I don't know.

+The story doesn't involve any destined" hero types that are done to death in a thousand other RPGs.  It is different enough to be enjoyable.
+I liked the characters.  They are less forgettable than in many RPGs.
+I liked the music.
+I like the battle system.
+It keeps a suitable amount of difficulty.  You can optionally level up higher than necessary to take on side-boss battles.

-It isn't free.
-I got nothing.

It isn't expensive(especially if you get it in a bundle).  Buy it.  Play it."

reviewText:
Quite a hars game @ the start! When you do not Level up from lv 1 it´s evry hard to even get the first win/s! But it get´s better the more you Level (they suddenly get pushed to good Stats)
As a RPG Maker lover i also like this game very much (Story is a very Interesting one!)
You´re not the Good guy´s haha..you also can kill ppl if you Talk to right one (haha she deserved it though somewhat)
As for the Gameplay is Typical battle like System but the World map is weird/facinating in the same time! (a 3D like Scroll world?! Well made, never saw anything like that!)
So far as i have played (second Kingdom finally arriving) the Story still seems to be good and i also meet someone i didnt thought i would see haha. Great Plot.

After getting more through. I noticed the characters look so simliar. Yeah some are family but even those are not looks too similar. Would have been better if there are more differences between the characters. As for the story i get tiny parts from time to time also a lot of bosses. And the equip sometimes is just getting a new one after new one when you just shortly chanced locations!
When you want to get the equip its also perfect for ahving the characters on a good level, so you have no problems killing a boss, bes ure to get the equip and the level ups while you do it you also get new skills 8some of em are hell good and sometimes needed. In the very early game you will need to level up to survive also and get the first good healing skill and after the ony ally healing you also get on around lv 7-8 a all ally healing which often saved my live by now!

@ first i thought they would bringt Darkness again over the world but it seems after Magus lost his power he became sane again. So while traveling with all you will have a lot of changes in your party meaning you shouldn´t focus on just one char making it perfect. Also Magus seem to be a grown up man who thinks for the best again. As that said they want to bring peace and save the rim kindoms from the threat they confront about.

After know finishing the game i quess it was just a Ending as i did had thought of. There are still some Extra´s i didnt finished due to power (i know of 4 extra´s where you need to be stronger than Final Boss!)
Also the game say´s something about a Continue + for the game (Credits in end)


Here is now a small list how i would give points for the game in each categorie:

Gameplay: 9/10 (Classic, yet its cool with Unique things!)

Graphics: 9/10 (Typical and also improved or enhanced Graphics!)

Support: ?/10 (never needed)

Price: 9/10 (5€ i got it for 0,99€ i think, it is stil worth the money also on full price)

Story: 9/10 (I am a RPG Lover so a Great Story is a must have for Games i play, i need to say this game was interesting all the way through the game!)

Sound: 8/10 (Music is very good, but can be Annoying if you want to play the game without Breaks. The Music feels annoying after a time.)

Performance: 8/10 (sometimes it lags a bit when i want to make fast moves like getting 2 chars ready with skill it lags due to the enhanced scripting they had made i quess)

FAZIT: 8.6/10 (Classic, improved RPG! Total worth the money and time you spend!)

reviewText:
I think I'm getting sick of RPG Maker games.
The outdated graphics, battle system, and overused stock items, characters avatars, etc. gets to be quite boring over time.
It's also worth nothing that the majority of RPG Maker games do NOT support Steam Overlay, so you can't even SEE the achievements you earn as you earn them, and you need to alt tab to see any messages. This is worth skipping games in the engine for that reason alone unless your not very social or don't care about Achievements, but I found this to be a negative.
I generally only play these games for the battle system, so I'm not really going to say much about the story, but the battle system is rather generic.
The problem I have with this game is that all you do in battles is use special moves and heal. As your team levels up, you will begin to do insane amounts of damage in the 1000s which means any weak attacks is a waste of time.
The flow of the game is basically going from one town/dungeon combo to another, fighting about three of the same enemies in boring dungeons using your most powerful specials, and buying ether to keep the MP up.
You will get a flock of similar characters (almost all female) to join you as you progress, but you will eventually find that only some of them are strong enough to invest your time in.
I did read a lot of the story, but I found it to be rather boring. The music and sound effects are nothing special either.
I never once considered this game to be fun, exciting, or creative.
There are better RPGs to play, using better more updated game engines. Don't waste your time or money here like I did.

reviewText:
It's, uh...not good.

This is an RPG-Maker game, which is a bad sign. In the right hands, RPG-Maker is a powerful tool that can be used to make a low-budget game that's actually worth playing. This isn't one of them.

It does a few somewhat interesting things: random battles can be seen ahead of time, thanks to a handy bar at the top of the screen on the world map; the characters will talk breifly after a battle is over; and the story is completely unorthodox - but despite these few redeeming traits, it's clear the author of the game has no idea how to really /make/ a game.

Yeah, you can move around and do things and fight things, but from the get-go the main character is extremely unlikable and we're given no reason to care whether he lives or dies. The story is also bizarre; when the game first started up, I thought it was going to be a reversal of the typical RPG hero story - y'know, where you play as the good hero from humble beginnings and gain strength and beat the bad guys. I was actually kind of excited to play through an evil overlord's rise to power. Then the game time-skips past all of that to when the empire is already formed. ...And that's about where I stopped playing.

I could go on, but I don't think I have to. It's really, really not worth your time. I'm sorry, game creator, but brush up on basic storytelling before trying anything like this.

reviewText:
Here are the pros, cons, and plot of this game:
\nPlot: Magus Lee was the child of Exodus Lee, who was in war with another kingdom. Magus was desperate to lead his father's forces in thier final push against their foes, but his father, being a Dark Lord, was cruel and belittled Magus. He denied Magus this chance, so Magus took matters into his own hands, and went to the battlefield. There, he confronted his father, and as they argued, the Dark God gifted Magus incredible powers. With this power, Magus killed both his father's and his father's enemies within seconds. He then banished his father to another land, and took his place of Dark Lord. Within the next few years, Magus took over many lands, but was soon defeated in a battle. From this, the Dark God took his powers away, leaving Magus helpless and weak. And now, he is rising in power again....


Pros: I somewhat enjoy the difficulty of the game. If you don't play just right, you'll need to grind and farm XP and Gold to buy potions, weapons, and armor. I also enjoy the idea of playing as an evil being, and how he is fighting another evil. With this, I enjoy how combat is played out, and how there is a random encounter meter in the open world. Finally, I like the dark humor in the story.

Cons: I dislike how much I have had to farm to get powerful enough to fight bosses, and I also dislike how magick users don't have as much MP as I would want and need to keep reviving and healing allies. Even with the humor, I don't like how it ruins the Dark feeling in the game.

Final Thoughts: I would recommend this game. I like how it runs, and how it feels. For those who want to try this, I recommend you buy it.

reviewText: This game has promise, but it can't even be played in full screen mode unless you lower your resolution because their engine doesn't support modern resolutions. This woudl be fine...if this game came out a decade ago and we were trying to play it on a modern machine. But, that isn't the case, this game is fairly new and when it was developed resolutions like 1900x1080 had already become one of the de facto standard resolutions. There's no reason for this game not to work in that resolution other than sheer laziness or ineptitude from the developers.

It's not a long review, so I strongly recommend you read all before mark this as a funny and useless review.


This game is the best proof of what happens when a game is voted on Greenlight in exchange for a key, It looks unfinished, has some bugs, and always when starts the game freezes for almost 20 seconds. When it reacts, the main menu is missing, and only get a black screen. If you press enter, the game loads properly, but it's annoying start the game blindly.

I can't make my MaxFire G12-U game controller works with this game. Having to use third party software to fix the problem can't be considered full controller support".

reviewText: I believe RPG maker game can be a good game. This one is not.
voteText: 16 of 40 people (40%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
if you like rpgs youll love this game, also yes i know rpg maker games are common but that does not make them bad, as each has another story to be told same as this one.
step inside the body of the dark lord venture thru mystry deciet and unlock the story behind the darklord.
you will face many foes, you will find many friends. but becareful as danger lurks behind every corner.

this is like many classic rpg styles, play as the hero defeat the evil, but this time ur one of evil, which choices to take a darker path then most to save the world.

might i also add expect laughs and suprises as you make your way thru this smashing hit.
become the dark lord, take over and make a kingdom of your own, then save the world? which is no small task.
pointing out this isnt your typical story of the knight and the evil.

i should note this is my 1st time playing an rpg maker game, and i find it delightful.
which for those who go rpg maker? meh, there is word that the game will be remade using the unity platform also.
so expect greatness <3

so the simple points ~ if you like rpg games, if you like a little spice of comedy including dark comedy.
with twists and turns at every corner full of suprises, not literly every corner but you get the idea ^w^ always something happening.
this is the game for you. classic rpg fans your in for a treat in this 8bit classic style rpg.
also be sure to checkout episode 2 which runs on a newer version of rpgmaker with changed up gameplay <3

also i frogot to add in this game can get very challanging as you move further into it, so expect to die alot if you arent careful, toughest as usual are the bosses which as said becareful ^w^


~update~
finished the game yesterday? under 20hours wise to beat final boss, but there is extra side quest things to do. but do be warned as ur playing thru the game read a walkthrough as some of the endgame side quests require u to have picked up this, or done that.
which there is a developers room which is only accessable via a certian one time thru area at the end.    ill say once again VERY challanging game.

which if you like tough rpgs this is a good one, i dont really care if people say oh its an rpgmaker game. because it doesnt matter its a great game worth playing, and i myself plan on replaying it to get the achivements, and doing every single thing <3

which thanks to the new rebirth update, there is now even more things to do including side quests so be sure to look for them ^w^


if this review is not helpful, please leave a comment as to why u feel that way so i may make changes if needed ^w^

reviewText:
EDIT: BE CARE, this game has some little bugs but the most hard is when you enter a dungeon and save a game without knew that you cannot back for farm, and you must fight an enemy too strong without any chance to farm. This will broke your game, and you will need to start the game from your other save states or... from the same begin again.


After said this...

I got this game from devs cause supported on Greenlight, so keep this in mind.

Well, just a couple of minutes playing but I like that though being a RPG Maker game, has a good custom battle system, menu and world view that shows care from developers. The BGM are really good. The only lack is: 1) So many time no play a RPG Maker and don't remind how to plug the controller untill I saw that I could put as first option on his own advanced properties device; 2) Some maps are a bit empty especially on inside tiles.

So, if you like JRPG's, want to be the bad guy and can afford some RPG Maker stylish... is good game to entertain.
